questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents to emergency department with fatigue and confusion. Patient’s radial pulse reveals regular beat-to-beat variability of pulse amplitude, although his rhythm is regular. Based on this, you suspect this patient has which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

This is a typical description of pulsus alternans-regular alteration of pulse amplitude seen in LV systolic dysfunction.

questions.text: Large a wave in JVP is seen in all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The causes of giant a wave is due to RA contraction against high resistance-RVH(PS,PAH),RVF (pulmonary embolism, RVMI) and tamponade.

questions.text: A patient has increased JVP on inspiration.All the following can be the cause except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

This clinical sign-JVP increasing on inspiration is known as Kussmaul sign.The causes are- constrictive pericarditis,restrictive cardiomyopathy,right ventricular failure and severe TS.

questions.text: Identify the auscultation area marked as number 3 in the diagram.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The area no. 1 is aortic area,2 is pulmonary area,4 is tricuspid area and no. 5 is apex.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with dyspnea, chest pain and light-headed on exertion. O/E-Pulse is slow rising with late peak. On auscultation systolic murmur, crescendo-decrescendo in nature heard best in the second right intercostal area. What is the cause of these clinical findings
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The classical symptoms of aortic stenosis are dyspnea + angina+ exertional syncope. The causes of AS are age related calcification, atherosclerosis (given in the question), RHD and bicuspid aortic valve. The murmur of AS is best heard at second right intercostal space (aortic area) and is ejection systolic (crescendo-decrescendo murmur).AR is early diastolic murmur, MS produces mid diastolic murmur and MR have pansystolic murmur.

questions.text: Identify the condition in which this low pitch sound marked as ? is heard
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This  sound is early diastolic sound which  could be opening snap(high pitch)caused by MS or TS or tumor plop(low pitch) caused by atrial myxoma.

questions.text: Murmur of mitral regurgitation is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The MR can be due to
1.RHD- chronic MR(Pansystolic murmur)
2.MI induced papillary muscle rupture-acute MR(early systolic murmur)
3.MVP induced MR(late systolic murmur).

questions.text: A 48 year old woman has a loud, high-pitched systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border, accompanied by a thrill. Which of the following conditions is likely present ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ventricular septal defect (VSD) causes a harsh systolic murmur that may radiate to the right side of the sternum. Atrial septal defect cause a quiet systolic flow murmur at pulmonary area. Persistent ductus arteriosus causes a continuous murmur throughout systole and diastole. Mitral valve prolapsed causes a late systolic murmur.

choices.text: Mixed aortic valve disease (aortic stenosis and aortic regurgitation)

questions.text: An 18-year-old man is referred for a murmur. The murmur is continuous. The differential diagnosis should include all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The causes of  continuous murmur are- arteriovenous fistulas,patent ductus arteriosus (best heard over the left infraclavicular area), ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm, coronary fistula, intrathoracic arteriovenous fistulae, severe coarctation of the aorta, and a surgically created shunt.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman has a raised C-reactive protein, a rash as shown in the figure, joint pain(without redness or increased temperature) of single joint area and fever.

How many Jones criteria of rheumatic fever are fulfilled here if this patient is from high prevalence area of rheumatic fever
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The lesion on skin is erythema marginatum(1 major) along with 3 minor criteria-fever,monoarthralgia and elevated C reactive protein.

questions.text: All of the following physical examination findings would suggest a diagnosis of aortic regurgitation except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Opening snap is seen in MS and TS. In AR two palpable systolic peaks can be present—the bisferiens pulse. The murmur of aortic regurgitation is a high-pitched “cooing” sound resulting from the high pressure difference between the aorta and left ventricular pressures during diastole. A mid diastolic rumble, the Austin-Flint murmur, may be heard in aortic regurgitation when an eccentric jet hits the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve, causing it to reverberate and generating the apical rumble.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman with severe aortic stenosis presents with dyspnea and worsening functional class in the setting of new-onset atrial fibrillation. Which of the following auscultatory findings would not be expected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

With onset of AF, S4 disappears as its needs atrial contraction.

choices.text: Prominent negative p wave in V1
T-wave inversions in II, III, aVF

questions.text: Which of the following ECG findings is least likely to be observed in  patient of mitral stenosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Atrial fibrillation (option A), atrial tachycardia, prominent negative p wave in V1 suggestive of LAE (option B), and an R wave in V1 due to RVH (option C) are classical electrocardiographic findings of mitral stenosis. T wave inversions in the inferior leads are not specific for mitral stenosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female with RHD and mitral stenosis is asymptomatic.No peripheral edema is present.ECHO revealed mitral valve area of 1.0 cm2.ECG is showing normal sinus rhythm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next recommendation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The patient’s examination is consistent with rheumatic mitral stenosis. Current guidelines recommend antibiotic prophylaxis for secondary prevention in patients with rheumatic fever and carditis. Diuretic therapy is recommended for patients with symptoms of heart failure.Balloon valvotomy recommended for severe and symptomatic MS.

questions.text: A 35 year old female with RHD presented come for routine check up. She has a pansystolic murmur at apex which radiated to axilla. Apex beat is displaced laterally.LVS3 is present. ECG shows sinus rhythm. On ECHO LVEF is 40% with regurgitant blood volume 70 ml/beat. What will be the appropriate step in management of this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This is a case of severe MR. Indications for surgery(preferably repair) are- NYHA symptoms >II, asymptomatic patient with LVEF<60% or atrial fibrillation or pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following complication is more common in mitral regurgitation as compared with mitral stenosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

LV failure is NOT seen in MS, its more common in late stages of mitral regurgitation.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

• Nocturnal angina and Key Hodgkin murmur(early diastolic murmur) is seen in AR
• Exertional syncope and reverse S2 split due to late A2 is a feature of severe AS
• Graham steell’s murmur is early diastolic murmur of pulmonary regurgitation
• Carvallo’s sign is pansystolic murmur of TR increasing on inspiration.

questions.text: Which of the following cardiac lesions has the highest risk of developing endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A MR is considered a relatively high-risk lesion for infective endocarditis. Mitral valve prolapse with regurgitation, asymmetric septal hypertrophy, and pure
mitral stenosis are considered an intermediate risk. Atrial septal defects of the secundum type are considered low risk

questions.text: A 65 year old man presents with a 4-week history of fever, general malaise and lethargy. He attends the emergency department and has blood cultures taken and he undergoes an echocardiogram, which shows a mass on his mitral valve. Conjunctival petechiae and tender finger tips are noted. What is the most likely organism that will be grown from his blood cultures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This patient has subacute IE(presentation > 2 weeks).Viridans streptococci is the most common cause of sub acute endocarditis .Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism from hospital acquired IE.Coagulase negative staphylococcus is the most common to infect prosthetic valves within one year and after one year its streptococcus viridans.

choices.text: A disease of the myocardium characterised by chamber enlargement and thinning of the left and right ventricular walls
A disease of the myocardium characterised by disproportionate thickening of the interventricular septum
A disease of the myocardium characterised by infiltration of myocardial tissue resulting in restricted contraction and relaxation
Isolated dilatation of the right ventricle, causing ventricular tachycardia

questions.text: Which of the following best describes dilated cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Dilated cardiomyopathy is characterised by dilatation of the atria and ventricles, and thinning of ventricular walls. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy causes disproportionate thickening of myocardium, particularly the interventricular septum. Myocardial infiltration (e.g. with amyloid protein) can cause restrictive cardiomyopathy, which does not cause cardiac dilatation but does restrict myocardial contraction and relaxation.

questions.text: A 55 year old woman presents with a history of acute, severe, constricting central chest pain associated with anterior ST segment elevation on the 12-lead ECG. She immediately undergoes coronary angiography, which shows no evidence of coronary artery disease and no coronary occlusion. An echocardiogram shows left ventricular apical dilatation, with normal left ventricular basal contraction. Which of the following factors is most likely to have precipitated this illness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Takotsubo (stress) cardiomyopathy occurs most often in females and is associated with
emotional stress. It is characterised by chest pain and ECG changes that mimic myocardial infarction. Troponin elevation is common but coronary angiography does not show occlusive coronary artery disease or intracoronary thrombus. Echocardiography shows a characteristic left ventricular
appearance of apical dilatation, giving the appearance of an octopus trap or takotsubo.

questions.text: A  48-year-old man presents with dyspnea. On examination, ejection systolic murmur at Erb’s area is present which increases in intensity with the Valsalva maneuver and with standing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Systolic murmur that becomes louder with manoeuvres that decrease preload, a cardinal physical examination finding present in hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy. Dilated cardiomyopathy can present with a third heart sound and murmurs of mitral and tricuspid regurgitation

choices.text: If A,B and C are correct
If A and C are correct
If B and D are correct
If all (A,B,C and D) are correct

questions.text:
Regarding restrictive cardiomyopathy 
A. Diastolic dysfunction 
B. Clinical features resemble constrictive pericarditis
C. ECG shows low voltage complex
D. Biventricular enlargement is characteristic
This question has four alternative/statements of which one or more will be correct.Answer using the following key
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Restrictive CMP is characterised by
• Diastolic dysfunction
• Biatrial enlargement
• Clinical features resemble constrictive pericarditis

questions.text: CHF is associated with increase in all the following except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

There is dilutional hyponatremia in CHF due to fluid retention. BNP is released from stretched ventricle. Nor epinephrine and TNF alpha are  released due to acute stress.

questions.text: Which of the following treatments is known to reduce risk of mortality in patients with dilated cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Loop diuretics have no effect on mortality in patients with cardiac failure. Rate-limiting calcium channel blockers such as diltiazem and verapamil are usually avoided, as they have a negative inotropic effect, which may aggravate cardiac failure. Aspirin and percutaneous coronary intervention are treatments for coronary artery disease, not cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 55 year old man comes to the emergency department due to 5 days of dyspnea. The patient's medical history is significant for long-standing hypertension and noncompliance with his antihypertensive therapy. Blood pressure Is 182/112 mm Hg and pulse is 110/min and regular Oxygen saturation Is 90% on room air. Lung auscultation shows bibasilar crackles. Which of the following Is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

This patient's presentation (dyspnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, bibasilar crackles, hypoxemia) is consistent with acute pulmonary edema, most likely due to acute decompensated heart failure.ADHF is most commonly due to acute myocardial infarction, arrhythmias,hypertension and acute severe mitral or aortic regurgitation) .This patient's ADHF is likely due to uncontrolled hypertension.Acute management of ADHF includes supplemental oxygen and intravenous loop diuretics.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with 2 days of chest pain. Pain is worsened with deep inspiration and relieved by leaning forward. On examination, there is pericardial rub. Electrocardiogram reveals diffuse ST segment elevation, which is concave upward in morphology. What is the next line management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Patient presents with acute pericarditis on the basis of typical history, friction rub on physical examination, and characteristic electrocardiographic and echocardiographic findings.

questions.text:
This ecg is seen in

 

<!--[if gte vml 1]> <![endif]--><!--[if !vml]--><!--[endif]-->
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

There is alteration in QRS amplitude known as electrical alternans typical seen in massive pericardial effusion/tamponade.

questions.text: Which of the following etiologies is not a cause of constrictive pericarditis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Commonly, no cause is found for constrictive pericarditis. Other causes include idiopathic, TB, CTD and malignancy. Rheumatic fever does not cause constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text: Restrictive cardiomyopathy is differentiated from constrictive pericarditis by which feature
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

There are 2 important clinical signs which differentiate RCMP from constrictive pericarditis-Apex beat(localised in RCMP and non localised in CP) and S4 present in RCMP and not seen in CP.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman diagnosed with ca lung presents with increasing dyspnea. On examination, BP is 80/60 mmHg, Her JVP is 15 cm above sternal angle. Her heart sounds are quiet.What is the most appropriate next diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The differential diagnosis of a patient with cancer presenting with dyspnea includes hematologic abnormalities, pulmonary embolism, paraneoplastic syndromes, infection, and cardiac causes. Beck’s triad is suggestive of cardiac tamponade. Cancers of the lung, breast, and kidney as well as hematologic malignancies, are the malignancies most likely to metastasize to the pericardium.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of diabetes, coronary artery disease (CAD), and hypertension has now developed diabetic nephropathy. Which of the following drug will be useful for managing hypertension?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

ACE inhibitors and ARBs have demonstrated a significant renal protective effect in the diabetic patient with nephropathy. Thiazide can impair diabetes control and beta blocker masks hypoglycemic awareness.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman has hypertension that is difficult to control. On physical examination, Blood pressure is 140/100 mmHg, and heart rate is 84 bpm. Laboratory studies reveal a potassium of 2.8 mEq/dL and a serum bicarbonate of 32 mEq/dL. Fasting blood glucose is 114 mg/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Conn’s syndrome leads to predominant diastolic hypertension without edema. There is also metabolic alkalosis with hypokalemia due to hyperaldosteronism.

questions.text: All of the following are potentially beneficial treatments for Prinzmetal angina except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Variant angina, also called Prinzmetal’s angina, is characterized by transient marked ST-segment elevation in the absence of plaque rupture and caused by coronary spasm. Nitrate relieves variant angina attacks within minutes.CCBs are very effective in preventing attacks.There is no documented role for beta-blockers.

questions.text: A 56 year old man presents with sudden onset of chest pain radiating down his left arm, ST segment depression of the ECG and elevated troponin..Which of the following treatments is likely to worsen his prognosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Non-ST segment myocardial infarction is normally initially managed with dual antiplatelet therapy (e.g. aspirin and ticagrelor), and an antithrombotic agent (e.g. fondaparinux or enoxaparin). β-Blockade is often used as prophylaxis against angina and arrhythmias. Intravenous tPA is a treatment for acute ST elevation myocardial infarction and has not been shown to improve outcome in patients with non-ST segment elevation myocardial infarction. Indeed, patients with ST segment depression have a worse outcome with thrombolytic therapy.

questions.text: A patient presented with chest pain and raised troponin-diagnosis of acute MI was made.There was complete heart block in ECG.What is the most likely culprit coronary artery was involved
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Complete heart block is due to AV node involvement. AV node is supplied by right coronary artery.

questions.text: A  68-year-old man is admitted with NSTEMI. On cardiac monitor there are few episodes of sustained ventricular tachycardia. In addition to aspirin, clopidogrel, beta blocker, heparin and nitrates, what is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

The indications of PCI in unstable angina/NSTEMI are-

 <!--[if gte vml 1]> <![endif]--><!--[if !vml]--><!--[endif]-->

choices.text: Transfer for primary percutaneous coronary angiography .
Administer half-dose thrombolytics and transfer to a PCI-capable facility.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man with a heavy smoking history presents with 6 hours of crushing substernal chest pain. On examination, he appears uncomfortable. An electrocardiogram of the patient is shown in Figure. BP is 110/70 and troponin levels are raised. 

A cardiac catheterization laboratory is 2.5 hours away, accounting for transfer time. In addition to aspirin, clopidogrel, morphine, oxygen, and nitrate therapy, what is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

This patient is having an inferior ST segment myocardial infarction. Time standards for reperfusion in the setting of STEMI include a “door-to-needle time” of 30 minutes or less if thrombolytics are chosen as the reperfusion strategy and a “door-to-balloon time” of 90 minutes or less if primary PCI is chosen as the reperfusion strategy. Timely PCI has been demonstrated to be superior to timely lytic therapy with improved patency of the infarct-related artery, less reinfarction, and less haemorrhagic complications. If a patient with STEMI presents to a non-PCI center, transfer for PCI should be considered if the first medical contact to device time is less than 120 minutes. In this case, there would be an unacceptable delay (2.5 hours) associated with transfer, and on-site full-dose thrombolytic should be administered.

questions.text: Identify the wall of myocardial infarction in this ECG
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

There is ST elevation in II,III and aVF s/o inferior wall MI.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male with a prior history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and tobacco abuse presents with chest discomfort during brisk walk. Tonight, it occurred while he was just sitting on the bench. He describes the discomfort as a pressure, radiating to his jaw. It typically lasts about 15 minutes. His ECG shows ST depression and  T-wave inversions in leads I,  aVL, V5, and V6.Troponin levels are normal. Which of the following clinical entities is an appropriate diagnosis for the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Unstable angina -chest discomfort is severe and has at least one of three features: (1) occurrence at rest (or with minimal exertion), lasting >10 min; (2) of relatively recent onset (i.e., within the prior 2 weeks); and/or (3) a crescendo pattern, i.e., distinctly more severe, prolonged, or frequent than previous episodes.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man with hypertension, dyslipidemia, and a smoking history presents with 6 hours of severe unrelenting chest pain. On examination, his blood pressure is 88/66 mm Hg. His jugular venous pressure is 14 cm above sternal angle and increases with inspiration. His lungs are clear. An electrocardiogram is shown in figure. Troponin levels are raised. 

In addition to administering aspirin and activating the cardiac catheterization laboratory, the most appropriate management is:

 

<!--[if gte vml 1]> <![endif]--><!--[if !vml]--><!--[endif]-->
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Inferior STEMI can be due to occlusion of the right coronary artery; The physical examination reveals a triad of hypotension, jugular venous distention with the Kussmaul sign, and clear lungs. This triad suggests a clinical diagnosis of right ventricular myocardial infarction. The right ventricle is unable to maintain left ventricular preload, leading to hypotension. The hypotension can be worsened markedly with nitrate therapy. Appropriate hemodynamic management includes judicious volume loading, often guided by a pulmonary artery catheter. The low left ventricular preload would be exacerbated by diuresis. Intravenous beta blockers should not be administered to patients in cardiogenic shock with acute myocardial infarction and would worsen hemodynamic in this case.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with 30 minutes of palpitations. Her symptoms began abruptly. A physical examination reveals a tachycardic, regular heart rhythm and blood pressure of 132/82 mm Hg. An ECG is shown in Figure. 

Carotid sinus pressure fails to terminate the arrhythmia. The next best step in management is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Electrocardiogram demonstrates a narrow complex regular tachycardia at approximately 150 beats per minute suggestive of PSVT. Vagal manoeuvres were an appropriate first step but were unsuccessful. Adenosine should be administered, which will be both diagnostic and possibly therapeutic by terminating AV node–dependent arrhythmias (AVNRT and AVRT) here is no need for DC cardioversion, because this patient is hemodynamically stable. Amiodarone is not indicated in this case.

questions.text: A 75 year old woman has a history of hypertension and diabetes. She presents with atrial fibrillation. What is her CHA2DS2-VASc score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The CHA2DS2-VASc score is used to assess stroke risk in patients with atrial fibrillation (and atrial flutter). The mnemonic takes account of clinical risk factors for stroke (C, congestive heart failure = 1 point; H, hypertension = 1 point; A2, age ≥ 75 years = 2 points; D, diabetes mellitus = 1 point; S2, previous  stroke or transient ischaemic attack = 2 points; V, vascular disease = 1 point; A, age 65–74 years = 1 point; Sc, sex category female = 1 point). In this case, the score is 5 points (2 points for age ≥ 75 years, 1 point each for female gender, diabetes and hypertension). This is associated with quite a high risk of stroke (approximately 5% annual risk if untreated) and this patient should be considered for oral anticoagulation

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is known to be effective in preventing stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Antiplatelet drugs are no longer recommended for stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation, although they are effective at preventing stroke due to carotid vascular disease. Amiodarone and β-blockers can help prevent atrial fibrillation episodes but are not known to reduce stroke risk. Apixaban is an oral factor Xa inhibitor, which has been shown in large-scale clinical trials to be effective at preventing stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation and moderate-to high stroke risk.

choices.text: Wenckebach (Mobitz type I) second-degree AV block
Mobitz type II second degree block

questions.text: Which conduction abnormality does this ECG show?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

In Mobitz type II second-degree AV block, most P waves conduct normally to the ventricles and are associated with a QRS complex. Some P waves do not conduct and there is no preceding increase in the P–R interval before the blocked P wave. This reflects block in the His–Purkinje system where conduction is ‘all-or-nothing’. In contrast, Mobitz type I second-degree AV block is characterised by progressive lengthening of the P–R interval block. This reflects block in the AV node itself, where conduction is ‘decremental’, i.e. the AV node exhibits signs of ‘fatigue’ with each successive beat

questions.text: Most likely diseased site in this ECG
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

This is junctional rhythm where AV node has become the pacemaker and will depolarise atria and ventricles simultaneously. QRS will hide P wave. The junctional rhythm occur due to SA node arrest.

choices.text: Each P will be followed by QRS
Each QRS will be preceded by P wave

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with coronary artery disease (CAD) presents with presyncope. His physical examination is normal except for bradycardia (pulse 56 beats/min) and an irregular pulse. The electrocardiogram (ECG) shows Wenckebach’s type atrioventricular (AV) block. Which of the following are you most likely to see on the ECG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Wenckebach, or type I second-degree AV block, is characterized on ECG by progressive lengthening of the PR interval until there is a nonconducted P wave.

choices.text: Intravenous bolus dose of magnesium sulphate

questions.text: A patient develops these ECG changes after an overdose of sotalol. Which one is NOT likely to be helpful in the management of this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

These are all useful interventions for torsades de pointes except procainamide. Magnesium sulphate reduces the risk of torsades without affecting the QT interval and is first-line treatment. Isoproterenol and pacing increase the underlying ventricular rate and reduce the risk of recurrence, as torsades is a bradycardia-dependent arrhythmia, although they are infrequently needed. Hypokalaemia worsens the risk of torsades, so correction  is beneficial. Procainamide is a class Ia anti-dysrhythmic drug that further prolongs ventricular repolarisation and would worsen the risk of torsades.

questions.text: All the following ECG changes are due to digoxin except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The digoxin effect on ECG-

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found with altered mental status. He is obtunded and unable to provide a history. You note a left brachial artery hemodialysis fistula in place. His initial ECG is shown in Figure. Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities would you expect to find in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Most likely patient is a case of CKD on hemodialysis and must have missed the dialysis session.This leads to hyperkalemia which is detected by tall T,wide QRS, absent P wave and sine wave pattern in the ECG.
